THE LITTLE THEATRE
North Howard at Franklin

"Snow" Ward, chairman of the
entertainment committee, wishes to
announce that there will be a dormitory dance Thursday evening,
February 16, for the residents and
their friends. The subscription is
$1.25 stag and $1.50 per couple. The
dance is informal and will be from
9 P. M. to 1 A. M. The Simpson-Morris orchestra will probably
furnish the music. Residents can
obtain tickets from members of the
entertainment committee. If this
dance is as successful as the first one
held before the Christmas recess, the
committee will probably undertake
to run a formal comparable to the
finest of dances.
The honor system is employed by
the management in checking up on
the number of windows broken by
each resident. The returns are not
as yet complete, so it is difficult to
estimate the total number of window
panes broken during the recent
snowfall. It will be interesting to
know who is the high scorer and
the runner-up. These two residents
can fight it out after the next snowfall.
The expenses incurred as a result
of the contest could be paid by
charging the residents a small admission fee. The high scorer could
be declared champion now, but it
doesn't seem right for one snowfall
to make a champion. The big factor in the contest between the high

scorer and the runner-up will be a
time limit of one hour. The time
element was entirely neglected during the last snowfall. In several
cases there has been considerable
disagreement as to the location of
the windows broken by each resident when two or more were throwing in the same direction.
Hereafter, it will be necessary for
the resident to call his shot, otherwise the shot will not be counted.
It is the business of the entertainment committee to draw up a set
of rules which will settle such important matters before the next
snow arrives.
If the "wagon" had been "backed
up" to the Dormitory as frequently
as Sergeant Frank threatened it
would be during the recent snow
battles, the driver of the "wagon"
would have been driving constantly
"backing up" to the Dormitory.

ENHANCING THE VALUE OF THE A. B. DEGREE
The announcement in today's NEWS-LETTER of the regulation
regarding the future status of sophomores and freshmen marks,
we believe, the first attempt on the part of an American college
to restrict the opportunities of the "liberal education" to those
"who give evidence by the character of their work that they should
be encouraged to acquire a liberal education." The terms of the
restriction are broad: they include both the student who has done
general good work and the student who has shown a particular
aptitude, although he may not have measured up to the given
standard generally.
No one can question the fairness of the step. We do not doubt
that many of those who will necessarily be dropped at the end of
the year will complain that they have not received justice, but
these men were warned at the beginning of the year that they
would not be permitted to remain in the University. And it is
better that such men leave after the end of their second year, for
few will maintain that a , person of average intelligence cannot achieve an average of 8.0 if he takes his education the least
bit seriously. If he does not regard the privilege of receiving an
education a sufficient incentive to proper application to his studies,
he is not deserving of that education. Similarly, if he is mentally incapable of meeting the standard, he is wasting his time by
staying in college four years.
The announcement does not state definitely just what is meant
by "marked ability." The very fact that a general average of 8.0
is required, however, makes it practically incumbent upon the
various departments to require an average of approximately 9.0
in their own work to recommend a student because of this
"marked ability." After all, the responsibility of the presence in
the University of a student whose average has been less than 8.0
lies with the department that allows him to stay.
We venture to predict that, inasmuch as the quality of the men
receiving the A. B. degree will be obviously particularly high in
the future, the University may find that it will be rendering a
greater service to the youth of Baltimore and at the same time
will remain faithful to the University's general policy if it should
continue to give the bachelor's degree indefinitely. This distinct
raising of the significance of the lower degree may, moreover,
not only cause Johns Hopkins to continue to graduate bachelors
of arts, but it may have a stimulating effect upon the value of the
degree in other institutions. Perhaps the immediate underlying
reason why there has been such a hue and cry raised in this country against the men graduated from American colleges has been
that the sheep are not separated from the goats. If every college
in the United States would allow only those to enter the third
year "who give evidence by the character of their work that they
should be encouraged to acquire a liberal education," the problem
of higher education would be a great step closer to solution.

Selections by the chorus of the
Glee Club and two piano solos by
Carl Lausch featured the Thursday
assembly. The program was presented in anticipation of the home
Concert of combined musical clubs,
Which is to take place at the auditorium of the Maryland Casualty club
house on February 24.
The first number sung by the
chorus was the University Ode,
Which is usually sung by the students at the opening of assemblies.
This was followed by "Sylvia" and
`0 Miss Hannah," in which the
group seemed to reach its maximum
effectiveness.

Osmar Steinwald, who wielded the
baton, explained that the Musical
Club is one of the oldest and most
important activities on the campus.
The organization, in some form, has
been in existence for forty-five
Years. As it now stands, it comprises the Glee Club, the Banjo Club,
the Hawaiian Group and the Blue
Jay Orchestra. When the current
season is over the combined clubs
Will have held eleven concerts, most
of them out of town. On February
20, the clubs will broadcast from
station WBAL, and on the ensuing Friday will be held the home
concert.
After the solos by Carl Lausch,
the chorus returned to sing a medley of Hopkins songs, which seemed
to arouse the greatest response from
the audience and received the most
sympathetic treatment by the singers.

"Snow" Ward, chairman of the
entertainment committee, wishes to
announce that there will be a dormitory dance Thursday evening,
February 16, for the residents and
their friends. The subscription is
$1.25 stag and $1.50 per couple. The
dance is informal and will be from
9 P. M. to 1 A. M. The Simpson-Morris orchestra will probably
furnish the music. Residents can
obtain tickets from members of the
entertainment committee. If this
dance is as successful as the first one
held before the Christmas recess, the
committee will probably undertake
to run a formal comparable to the
finest of dances.
The honor system is employed by
the management in checking up on
the number of windows broken by
each resident. The returns are not
as yet complete, so it is difficult to
estimate the total number of window
panes broken during the recent
snowfall. It will be interesting to
know who is the high scorer and
the runner-up. These two residents
can fight it out after the next snowfall.
The expenses incurred as a result
of the contest could be paid by
charging the residents a small admission fee. The high scorer could
be declared champion now, but it
doesn't seem right for one snowfall
to make a champion. The big factor in the contest between the high

scorer and the runner-up will be a
time limit of one hour. The time
element was entirely neglected during the last snowfall. In several
cases there has been considerable
disagreement as to the location of
the windows broken by each resident when two or more were throwing in the same direction.
Hereafter, it will be necessary for
the resident to call his shot, otherwise the shot will not be counted.
It is the business of the entertainment committee to draw up a set
of rules which will settle such important matters before the next
snow arrives.
If the "wagon" had been "backed
up" to the Dormitory as frequently
as Sergeant Frank threatened it
would be during the recent snow
battles, the driver of the "wagon"
would have been driving constantly
"backing up" to the Dormitory.

ENHANCING THE VALUE OF THE A. B. DEGREE
The announcement in today's NEWS-LETTER of the regulation
regarding the future status of sophomores and freshmen marks,
we believe, the first attempt on the part of an American college
to restrict the opportunities of the "liberal education" to those
"who give evidence by the character of their work that they should
be encouraged to acquire a liberal education." The terms of the
restriction are broad: they include both the student who has done
general good work and the student who has shown a particular
aptitude, although he may not have measured up to the given
standard generally.
No one can question the fairness of the step. We do not doubt
that many of those who will necessarily be dropped at the end of
the year will complain that they have not received justice, but
these men were warned at the beginning of the year that they
would not be permitted to remain in the University. And it is
better that such men leave after the end of their second year, for
few will maintain that a , person of average intelligence cannot achieve an average of 8.0 if he takes his education the least
bit seriously. If he does not regard the privilege of receiving an
education a sufficient incentive to proper application to his studies,
he is not deserving of that education. Similarly, if he is mentally incapable of meeting the standard, he is wasting his time by
staying in college four years.
The announcement does not state definitely just what is meant
by "marked ability." The very fact that a general average of 8.0
is required, however, makes it practically incumbent upon the
various departments to require an average of approximately 9.0
in their own work to recommend a student because of this
"marked ability." After all, the responsibility of the presence in
the University of a student whose average has been less than 8.0
lies with the department that allows him to stay.
We venture to predict that, inasmuch as the quality of the men
receiving the A. B. degree will be obviously particularly high in
the future, the University may find that it will be rendering a
greater service to the youth of Baltimore and at the same time
will remain faithful to the University's general policy if it should
continue to give the bachelor's degree indefinitely. This distinct
raising of the significance of the lower degree may, moreover,
not only cause Johns Hopkins to continue to graduate bachelors
of arts, but it may have a stimulating effect upon the value of the
degree in other institutions. Perhaps the immediate underlying
reason why there has been such a hue and cry raised in this country against the men graduated from American colleges has been
that the sheep are not separated from the goats. If every college
in the United States would allow only those to enter the third
year "who give evidence by the character of their work that they
should be encouraged to acquire a liberal education," the problem
of higher education would be a great step closer to solution.

The Yale Daily News celebrated

Athletic officials at Stanford University have advocated the adoption
of the two-team football system
which will be given a tryout at a
number of mid-western colleges next
season. It is proposed that the entire squad be divided into one team,
consisting of seniors, and another of
juniors, with sophomores substituting on both elevens. Neither team
would be known as the varsity, but
would be called A and B, respectively. Each would represent the
University on alternate Saturdays.
The senior team would play their
traditional rivals, the University of
California.

Dr. John G. Hubben, president
of Princeton University, maintains
that the average student has too
much money to spend in college.
He states that the contributing
causes to the failure of undergraduates in their courses are: Motion
pictures, over-indulgence in extracurricular activities, and the excessive generosity of parents.

The University of Maryland's
football authorities have instituted
a new idea in the election of future
football captaincies. In 1928
.
there
will be no election by the team itself.
Before each game acting field captains will be appointed by the coach.
At the end of the season the letter
men will meet and elect a captain
whose position will, of course, be
purely honorary. This move has
long been threatening at Maryland,
where fraternity politics have been
the cause of some little friction,
and the step has finally been taken
in an effort to combat this evil.
